channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title:
In Opinion
"How do we ask young people just starting out, or older people who have seen so much progress reversed, to care about a country that seems so determined to care so little for them?" asks Pamela Paul. https://t.co/zhQ5c9fwAo

The Vatican released thousands of letters from Jewish people begging for help during the Holocaust to "allow the descendants of those who asked for help to find traces of their loved ones from any part of the world," its foreign minister said. https://t.co/hQjVQbo2RO
Breaking news: The U.S. and the rest of the G7 nations will ban imports of gold from Russia, aiming to undercut a key source of revenue amid its war in Ukraine. https://t.co/YxSVnpiZaP

Two people were killed and at least 19 injured early Saturday morning in downtown Oslo when a gunman opened fire outside two nightclubs and a diner, the police and Norway’s state broadcaster said. https://t.co/fmcbxg4f5v

Companies that have said they would cover travel expenses for employees who need abortions include Starbucks, Tesla, Yelp, Airbnb, Netflix, Patagonia, DoorDash, JPMorgan Chase, Levi Strauss & Co. and Reddit. https://t.co/KDbGkHEauN
For Amy Gutmann, a respected democracy scholar, her role as President Biden’s envoy to Germany is not a job. "It’s a mission," she said. https://t.co/JAGgd6Ykdc https://t.co/X4YflIbKOe
A slow-burning hostility to constitutional abortion rights runs through the career of Justice Samuel Alito, the author of the Supreme Court opinion overturning Roe v. Wade. https://t.co/pjJEdEVXfN

After signing into law the bipartisan gun bill at the White House on Saturday morning, President Biden was asked by a reporter if he thought the Supreme Court was broken.
"I think the Supreme Court has made some terrible decisions," he said. https://t.co/MuTJBcHE7i https://t.co/NtqilLWmyv

In her latest letter to Democratic lawmakers about the decision to end Roe v. Wade, Speaker Nancy Pelosi said the Supreme Court was "guilty of a miscarriage of justice." https://t.co/sLRt2YJ76A https://t.co/vimEO7cVXL

The Broadway farce "POTUS" features a moment in which a character blurts out that she volunteers at an abortion clinic in Iowa. On Friday night, her line saying that "affordable, safe reproductive health care is a basic human right" stopped the show. https://t.co/JXmiMj57FO https://t.co/q9Hf5hz4BN

The list of companies that have said they will cover travel expenses for employees in need of abortions continues to grow, including H&M, Bank of America and Intuit. Google said employees could apply to relocate "without justification." https://t.co/ZnP6Frej7o

During a two-hour meeting in 2018, Senator Susan Collins of Maine pressed Brett Kavanaugh on why she should trust him not to overturn Roe v. Wade.
Meeting notes show Kavanaugh worked vigorously to reassure her that he was no threat to the landmark ruling. https://t.co/1jUW6ypGVT

Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida signed a law in April banning abortions after 15 weeks of pregnancy, severely curtailing access to the procedure. On Friday, he praised the Supreme Court’s decision, saying "the prayers of millions have been answered." https://t.co/RmlIFg9H8z

In Arizona, police deployed tear gas and state senators called a recess late Friday after abortion rights protesters amassed outside the State Capitol, with some banging on the glass. https://t.co/AC0oyvYspk

Meta, which owns Facebook and Instagram, told its workers not to openly discuss the Supreme Court’s ruling overturning Roe v. Wade on wide-reaching communication channels inside the company. https://t.co/LIisUqyHKX

A shooting near a popular gay club in downtown Oslo that killed two people and seriously wounded at least 10 is being investigated as an act of terrorism, as Norwegians grappled with a rare gun attack that shattered an expected Pride weekend celebration. https://t.co/N8IRrL8abx

All six Supreme Court justices in the majority opinion striking down Roe v. Wade avoided directly stating in their confirmation hearings how they would rule on it. They typically stuck to expressing their belief in the importance of precedent. https://t.co/7n2bQRyKKL https://t.co/VTaE7XJPPj
This was the New York Times front page on the day in 1973 that the Supreme Court decided Roe v. Wade in a 7-2 vote. https://t.co/EZMsBqhCtq

In Opinion
"While his wife ran around helping Trump with his coup, Thomas was the senior firebrand in a coup of extremists on the court," @maureendowd writes. https://t.co/ZJ4ApCTj99

Taking pills to end a pregnancy accounts for a growing share of abortions in the U.S.
Now that the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, medication abortion will play a larger role, especially among women who lose access to abortion clinics. https://t.co/6oRc2pyodq
The front page of The New York Times for Saturday, June 25, 2022. https://t.co/l94XJdVttu

Clinic escorts directed traffic outside the Jackson Women’s Health Organization in Mississippi as a small group of anti-abortion demonstrators gathered outside following the Supreme Court reversal of Roe v. Wade. https://t.co/WHRuIft8YM https://t.co/gLbO1LhA3k
Many governments around the world have been moving toward easier access to abortion, with more than 50 countries liberalizing their laws in the past three decades. https://t.co/vONrNUAp4A

Advocates for LGBTQ rights on Friday sounded the alarm over Justice Clarence Thomas’s concurring opinion overturning Roe v. Wade, calling it a potential assault on the legal doctrine protecting a wide array of Americans’ civil rights. https://t.co/T1m2LxRpzb
Hours after the U.S. Supreme Court ruled to overturn Roe v. Wade on Friday, thousands gathered in New York City to voice their fears and rage over the decision. https://t.co/SNqFZJz6JL

Abortion funds, the local organizations that provide financial and logistical support for people seeking abortions, have received millions of dollars in new funding after the Supreme Court struck down Roe v. Wade on Friday. https://t.co/QjPCBQLEKN https://t.co/YXuO6DfjCs

Mike Pence, the former vice president under Donald Trump and a likely Republican presidential candidate in 2024, praised the Supreme Court’s ruling on abortion, saying, “Today, Life won.” https://t.co/8XPsVOrQ36 https://t.co/5BIBdofj3e

From @nytopinion:
So much for precedent. Before they were confirmed, this is what Justices Kavanaugh, Thomas, Gorsuch, Alito and Coney Barrett had to say about Roe v. Wade. https://t.co/1ZZ33Ccp2K

Now that the Supreme Court has struck down Roe v. Wade, the most important election this year in America when it comes to abortion will be the contest for governor of Pennsylvania. https://t.co/nxzvLcxXkT

Hundreds of protesters gathered in front of the Supreme Court to condemn the decision to overturn Roe v. Wade. Next to the protesters, anti-abortion activists celebrated the end of the landmark ruling. https://t.co/847J2vGztX https://t.co/phDsKf8UpM

Megan Rapinoe, the star of the U.S. women’s soccer team, was among several athletes to criticize the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade. She said it was “oddly cruel” timing as women celebrate the 50th anniversary of Title IX legislation. https://t.co/nfcXamfPDc

Prior to his confirmation hearing, Brett Kavanaugh worked vigorously to reassure Sen. Susan Collins that he was no threat to Roe v. Wade, according to notes obtained by The New York Times from their two-hour conversation in August 2018. https://t.co/WU5GFl53lU https://t.co/ju0oRUSzcX

This map shows how far a woman in the U.S. needed to drive to reach an abortion clinic with Roe v. Wade in place. Within weeks, abortion will be outlawed in many states, and the map will start to change. https://t.co/spBgB1x2Uf
Senator Mitch McConnell spoke on the ruling to overturn Roe. v Wade on Friday. He arguably shaped the Supreme Court that handed down this decision. https://t.co/wfhjVjv8FN https://t.co/lebRo8apsW
Anti-abortion demonstrators celebrated in front of the Supreme Court on Friday morning after the 6-3 ruling that overturned Roe v. Wade. https://t.co/OWyFF2GAv5 https://t.co/dOrwVfDzcp

Women who were denied an abortion had more psychological problems in the short term than those who received one, and also experienced more long-term physical and financial problems, landmark research known as the Turnaway study found. https://t.co/dhSB1cU0ZX

Abortion is now banned in at least nine states, with trigger bans in several more set to take effect in the coming days. Laws in eight states took effect on Friday after the Supreme Court ruled to overturn Roe v. Wade. https://t.co/urnXjV1uNF https://t.co/3pYUVKlmvA

Erriyon Knighton, 18 years old and just out of high school, has already lowered Usain Bolt's world junior sprinting record in the 200 meters. "It's almost like he's a pogo stick," Knighton's coach said. https://t.co/mrXaA189Y7

Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York condemned the Supreme Court overturning Roe v. Wade on Friday as “repulsive.” She said it was a “dark day for women across this nation” who have “long fought for the right to have control over their own lives.” https://t.co/5MstqS6wVO https://t.co/SW9npKtcZX

Attorney General Merrick Garland vowed to use the Justice Department’s authority to protect abortion rights and said states cannot ban the FDA-approved abortion pill mifepristone. https://t.co/m2HjGyAkSz

Dick’s Sporting Goods said it would provide up to $4,000 in travel reimbursement for employees who live in states that restrict abortion access and that the policy would apply to any spouse or dependent covered by the company’s medical plan. https://t.co/xO775TTQ9Y

The decision by five Supreme Court justices to end the constitutional right to abortion has cast a renewed spotlight on what they said about Roe v. Wade during their confirmation hearings. Here is a sampling: https://t.co/8oYkmTPFsX https://t.co/sRw3ZIpdKb

A protester outside the Supreme Court said she was on a train from New York back to her home in Virginia on Friday morning, but decided to get off when the train reached Washington, getting a sign on her way. https://t.co/dZWSQVp3nb https://t.co/RqLrsNwN8O
The Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade could deal a blow to the financial well-being of women, who will bear a steep economic burden from unwanted pregnancies. https://t.co/l2GsDtplXY

Donald Trump has privately told friends and advisers that he believes the Supreme Court decision ending Roe will anger suburban women, a group who helped tilt the 2020 election to Joe Biden, and lead to a backlash against the GOP in the November midterms. https://t.co/UxeuYADtCy https://t.co/WHuEx0bBsA

The decision by five Supreme Court justices to end the constitutional right to abortion has cast a renewed spotlight on what they said about Roe v. Wade during their confirmation hearings. Here is a sampling: https://t.co/KjW3MFhbqY

Senator Susan Collins, the Maine Republican who was a key supporter of Brett Kavanaugh in his 2018 confirmation, said he and Neil Gorsuch misrepresented their views on Roe v. Wade in private meetings with her. https://t.co/RWNdmks29h https://t.co/r6m4yeS0cF

The Supreme Court's decision to overturn Roe v. Wade and give individual states the choice of banning or allowing abortions will immediately affect 13 states that have trigger laws. https://t.co/ppj1MChGaQ https://t.co/SeYIUewsM8

Attorney General Merrick Garland called the Supreme Court's decision to strike down Roe v. Wade “a devastating blow to reproductive freedom,” and he vowed to use the Justice Department’s authority to protect the right to abortions. https://t.co/FPF3Tspnv1 https://t.co/7Vv6frMdS7

Donald Trump is the man most responsible for shaping the Supreme Court that delivered the conservative movement a victory in overturning Roe v. Wade. But privately, he has told people repeatedly that he believes the decision will be “bad for Republicans.” https://t.co/Ph5GcjIXJr
